This is my submission to the "Make It Loud" challenge. It is a ten-in-one whistle combo that shrieks with 10 independent tone holes and channels. According to my iPhone 5s app, "Decibel 10th", the Quadtone Blastoid read at 103 decibels (three consecutive trials per the attached screenshot)... not a bad showing but I was sure I could do better. So, I isolated the loudest hole from the Quadtone Blastoid and just repeated that geometry for all 10 of the Decatone Blastoid holes. The result is the most shrill thing I've ever heard, even though it takes a lot of breath to get it going with all 10 holes exposed. So, just as the picture above suggests, cover some of the holes so that you can get a louder and more sustained blast according to your lung capacity. Nonetheless, I still read 103 db max (though I can clearly hear one is louder than the other)... so I may be saturating my iPhone's capacity to register high-amplitude sound waves. Also, I rounded the mouthpiece so that you can hook up an air compressor to this thing, if you dare. :) I've posted an image of the Quadtone Blastoid in the "I Made One" area if you want to check out my work prior to arriving at the Decatone. Here's the vid of the Decatone Blastoid demo on youtube with 6, 5, 4 holes covered, respectively. How many can you leave uncovered to produce the loudest sound on one breath? https://youtu.be/qusP5rm-iW8 Nov 29th, 2015 update: if you don't want to use up so much of your breath to blow on this thing to make a brief (albeit loud) sound, here are a couple of practical alternatives that are almost as loud as this one, but require far less effort to blow (without covering holes, that is): http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1162032

The spirit of thinkFun is providing a minimal set of building tools that can interact with the ordinary and the everyday in fun and surprising ways. All you have to do is think fun!
I wrote a parametric thinkFun Connector Library in order to make making custom connectors easier for everyone. I took thinkFun’s open source connector STL and chopped it into an end cap and a midsection, and then rebuild it with any number of holes. Now we can have classic thinkFun connectors of any length. It’s not truly open source until its parametric!
Once the classic connector was built, the midsection and end caps could be redesigned and reassembled into new types of thinkFun connectors. 
The Clip Connector.I designed a connector with a clip on one side for attaching pieces of cardboard. 
The Slot Connector. This connector has a horizontal slot through the middle. I imagine printing a bunch of these and running a piece of fabric through them and connecting it together in a loop — creating a tank tread!
The Lego Connector. This connector is fun for adding in basic lego-connectivity. Mini-figures can now easily ride along and lego plates can add structural support to your designs.
The Bent Connector. This connector makes a good angle bracket for building a chassis or other rigid structures.
The Flexible Connector. This is bendable connector that would work great as a shock absorber for a vehicle, or a spring action for a catapult, or even just as a non-linear connector.
The Narrow Connector. Sometimes the width of the connector is too much. This narrow connector offers a slimmer version of the classic connector.
The Grooved Connector. This connector has groove instead of holes. It could be used adding mechanical motion like for train wheels or legs on a robot.
There are a several other ways to make connectors. The first thing that comes to my mind is curved connector with H many holes and X amount of arc. At any rate, this library can be used to quickly create the connectors listed, and it can easily be extended to make even more types of connections. All you have to do is thinkFun!

author: lidsdad

description.text: I often use herb grinders (like http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:20168) to get herbs to manageable sizes. I found myself using the kitchen counter or a square tray and it was always a pain to clean. I created this herb tray with rounded edges so there are no corners for particles to get stuck in. I printed this version here and it worked great. I then added a an optional lip too, so pick the design that will work best for you. Dimensions of the two options are very similar. After printing looks like the version with lip is a little taller, but skinnier. Suggestions welcome, happy herb moving!

Files are ready to print. The only thing to customize is the size of the tray (length and width), then I suggest turning off the ratio lock and editing the height.   
I used a .20mm layer height, 15% infill, 230 degrees.

description.text:
Hard case to protect the lenses of the Ricoh Theta camera.
Updated size to fit the slightly larger Theta S camera.
Push the hard case to the bottom of the soft case for added protection.

Update 12/21/2016:
Uploaded the FreeCAD file. My Cobblebot has a large print area and the bowden tube is about 3' long to accommodate this size. With the twist that comes from the tubing being coiled during shipping and the twisting caused by the filament it would create too much back pressure and my extruder couldn't push the filament through the hotend. Picking up the tube and holding in "straight' would alleviate the problem. While the tube could be shorter I like the smother radius of a longer tube to minimize back pressure on the extruder. While it is minimal if you use a tube that's just long enough to cover your bed area it will increase the work on the steppers. They need to overcome the resistance of the tubing as it bends. I also seen twisting/bending in much shorter tubes causing high resistance to the extruder drive. I designed this clip to align the Bowden tube using a large (in this case 36") tie wrap as a support. I originally tie-wrapped the tubing to the larger one but that was a pain to take out when I had a plugged extruder or do other work. The before picture of my tube is straighter than it was before this solution. It has be tie-wrapped to the the large tie-wrap for a couple weeks and was still holding some shape. This is for a thinner tie-wrap a bit less the 2mm thick. It won't work on the thicker Thomas and Betts (T&B) tie-wraps as they are significantly thicker. Also buy tie-wraps that are packaged without coiling. The coil stays in the plastic and won't be a good support. I did this in OpenSCAD but the code isn't pretty so I didn't include the source. Lot's of trial and error to make a clip that fit. I can provide the source if anyone is interested. Update:
This was designed for 4mm diameter tubing and the large tie-wrap has a cross section of 2mm x 8mm.

Printer:

Cobblebot Basic

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

70%

Notes: Probably doesn't need this high of infill but clip shouldn't break when snapping onto the tubing. I show seven printed, six should be more than adequate for any shorter tubing.

description.text: After spending hours on end trying to manifest a shape that lookedsome-what like a blender i have completed my goal in my second revison. My first verson of the blender didn't inclulde a base that was lofted and a small section of the hopper that was not lofted giving it a more realistic look.This small model was created for an inside joke between friends and has no functional perpose but acting as a paper weight.I Hope to refine the model and include more features such as a handel and more realistic looking buttons.

• Download .stl file.
  • Open in ReplicatorG. Resize if desired and insure that the model is set on the base.
  • Create G-code.
  • Turn on MakerBot Thing-o-matic(with heated base platform).
  • Make sure intended color of ABS plastic filament is loaded.
  • Connect to machine.
  • Print.
  • Watch for the durration of the print.
  • Allow time for the print to cool, remove any excese plastic.
  • Enjoy.

While it is a functional case at the moment, I would like to improve it, especially the snap-in lid, so please leave comments if you have suggestions on how to improve it, or feel free to remix! description.text:
This is a support for the Printrbot Simple Metal. In my experience, the printer really likes to tip over with the spool holder at the top of the printer and especially with the extended X axis.
These supports keep the printer from tipping over even at the max Z and X limits and with a full spool of filament. As a bonus, rubber feet can be put on the bottom of the supports to dampen some of the printer noise.

Beholder 3D Scanner made of threaded rod Made with threaded rod, do not need frame.
Just printed parts, bars, nuts and washers.
Strong printed parts and strong body.
Cheap, Simple, Elegant.
Easy to print and mount, small parts and no big bearing.
  • Derivation of object Ciclop 3D scanner by bqLabs:
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:740357

  • Drivers, software and manuals:
    http://www.bq.com/gb/support/ciclop
    • This scanner is a collaboration project of:
    http://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/reprapbr
    Grupo Reprap Brasil - Obrigado a todos. You can help me to do more things like this.
    Buy my designs at pinshape:http://pinshape.com/users/27920-jsirgado
    The OpenSCAD file is there, you can change all.

I joined the pieces in plates:
  • Plate_Parts.stl;
  • Plate_Body.stl;
  • Plate_Table.stl;
    • But you can print all in separated.
    See the photos and the blue print images to mount all. All you need:
  • All the 3d printed parts(see the plates).
  • 2x threaded rod 8mm diameter with 1 meter, then cut all:
    2x 180mm for x frame;
    2x 400mm for y frame;
    2x 200mm for z frame;
    4x 80mm for motor fix;
    4x 50mm for bearing fix;
  • 4x bearing for table support:
    4x model 608 8mm x 22mm x 7mm;
  • 1x transparent acrylic plate for the table:
    200mm diameter and ~5mm height;
  • 1x stepper motor nema 17 with 20mm shaft:
    12v ~1.5a ~3.2Kgf/cm;
  • 1x DC power suply:
    12v ~2a ~25w recommended;
  • 1x logic board:
    Arduino Uno or Arduino Nano;
  • 1x shield SUM for 3D Scanner or similar.
  • 1x motor driver pololu A4988 or similar.
  • 3x Jumper for pololu driver setup.
  • 1x USB cable ~2m(computer to scanner).
  • 1x webcam Logitech model C270 HD720p.
  • 2x red line laser module with 12mm x 35mm:
    5V 5mw 650nm focus and industrial grade recommended;
  • 6x screws for motor and motor gear:
    3mm diameter and ~10mm height;
  • 10x screws for table, camera and lasers:
    4mm diameter from 20mm to ~35mm height;
  • Lots washers and nuts for body:
    56x 8mm nuts (optional some locking nuts);
    60x 8mm washers;
    Nuts and washers for 3mm and 4mm screws;
    • Attention:
  • There is one nut inside each laser_fix;
  • There are two nuts in the motor_gear;
  • For the bearings do not use washers greater than 16mm;
  • All table weight go to the bearings;
  • The top of motor_gear is 1mm below the bottom of the table;
  • The camera need fits in the camera_fix, do not use force;
  • If your laser is smaller than 12mm diameter, use a strip of paper to adjust;
    • Use my other objects to improve your 3D Scanner:

  • Ciclop 3D Scanner shield:
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1154668

  • Arduino case:
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:319733
    • If you have problems with your slicer software,
    please use the files:     power_fix_fixed.stl; table_base_fixed.stl; Plate_Parts_fixed.stl; Plate_Table_fixed.stl; That is all.

description.text:
Macro-Toolbox Mental Blossoming Lamp is a mental controlable lamp.
You can use it to train your attention/concentration and meditation skills.
Demo video :
https://youtu.be/caP1dLanq6c This is my own version of the blossoming lamp of Emmett and the bloom of Puzzlebox.
Design was very slighty modified, but hardware and software has been significantly optimized (no more need to use a phone as an interface between the EEG headset and the lamp).
Overview of modifications are listed bellow and a full Design, Hardware, Software and Assembly guide is available at the link :
http://www.macro-toolbox.com/toolbox/mental-blossoming-lamp/ This lamp is :
  • 3d printable with any 3d printer having a printable volume of 130x130x130.
  • filled with simple electronic hardwares (as arduino board, bluetooth module, led, servo motor,…).
  • fully open source (design, hardware and software and you can adapt it to your needs.
  • controlable with a EEG headset (currently a neurosky mindwave mobile headset) with bluetooth communication.
    • Design was :
    Initiated by emmett and his Blossoming Lamp :
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:37926
    Adapted by Puzzlebox to allow the inclusion of hardware and the motorization :
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:618490
    And finaly I modded the bulb to make it nicer and allow its printing on my 3d printer. Hardware was :
    Initiated by Puzzlebox and,
    Modded by macro-toolbox to add the following ameliorations :
  • headset can communicate directly with the lamp.
  • contrary to puzzlebox version, you don't need a ble bluetooth board and a ble bluetooth device (phone or tablet) as an interface between the headset and the lamp.
  • added a power board to drive the servo and to support the bluetooth module.
    • Software was :
    Based on Neurosky Arduino example found at neurosky.com for the mindwave protocol and,
    Fully written by macro-toolbox to control the lamp features (light and motorization), at the exception of a bit of puzzlebox code for the rgb loop crossfade.

**update Dec 14, 2015
Luer lock is now printable... but can still be improved. The opening ends up being very small, so a small drill or a hot needle passed through it might be a good idea. Doesn't seem to fully lock either... needle continues to spin when I turn it
...The hole is now bigger, but it doesn't seem to be liquid tight when I print it.. and it still continues to spin when I turn a needle in it. A luer-lock to be added to models that deal with fluids. The scaling hasn't been optimized for FFF printers (tolerances are too tight)... The centre needs to be scaled down, and the outside ring needs to be scaled up. It would probably be good to print with a higher resolution printer, like an SLA one though.

title: Flower Fobs... Flower Key Fobs that Spin!

description.text:
This small print will be popular with everyone from your Mum, Sister, Girl Friend, Aunty etc. A quick easy and unique gift idea... There are two types... one that has the side not attached to the keys that rotates / spins freely. The other type is a simple fixed key fob (no rotation / movement) and is the .stl titles 'solid'.. Pause your print part way through to create a unique Flower Fob in the colours of choice. Approximate colour change points 'with a 1mm Raft' are: First Change: 4mm / 48%
Second Change: 8mm / 76% Please refer to the print settings and images for additional details and to see the result... Flower Fobs (with Raft) only use 6gm of filament and take half an hour to print (on a Replicator 2). At standard scale a Flower fob (excl. attachment end) is 30mm in diameter. The rotating type is a print-in-place design that does not require any automated support. A small support block has been designed in to support the Key Ring attachment. This should cut away relatively easily. Fine clearances are used so some machines may not be accurate enough to achieve a free spinning Flower Fob at standard scale. The simple solution to address this is uniformly scale it up a fraction to increase the clearances. Note: If you like this check out all my other fun and practical designs.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.20mm / Standard

Infill:

2 Shells / 75% / PLA

Notes: Use high infill percentage to ensure this is strong and durable when attached to a key ring. Do not use automated support. This could build structures internally so the rotating type would not rotate. The one small piece of support required has been designed in. This should snap away relatively easily after printing (refer to images provided) Pause your print part way through to create a unique Flower Fob in the colours of choice. Approximate colour change points 'with a 1mm Raft' are: First Change: 4mm / 48%
Second Change: 8mm / 76%
Remove raft and designed-in support block. Just cut the raft of, snap away the designed-in support block then wiggle the two halves (of the rotating type) to free your Flower Fob to spin.

comments.text: Sorry to hear you're having issues with this print. What you've described could be being caused by a number of factors including slicing app and / or machine precision and accuracy as well as filament quality and condition. The simple solution in many cases is just uniformly scale it up by 5 - 10% as that will increase the internal clearances.

title: Christmas Tree Star / tree topper - tweaked

description.text:
My daughter wanted a star to put on top of her small Christmas tree.
I went to print the original I found on here in Cura but it came up solid rather than hollow. I flattened out the bottom, rotated it up to be standing up, and hollowed it out. There is also a 10cm-tall version with MeshMixer supports. There is a hidden support inside the star itself that I didn't realize was there until I was ready to print, and didn't care enough to remove.

author: dgsharp

description.text: So you drank an mini keg and you don't want to throw it away?    I have an answer for you. I turned my Hineken mini keg into a portable radio.

So I bought a 110Vac to 12.6Vac transformer and rectified it to 12.5VDC. Then I hooked up the head unit to the 12V DC source, this is not hard but the wiring depends on the type of head unit. I also added a 12V to 5V DC buck converter to power two female usb outlets. I designed and printed the two brackets to hold the keg in place and the speaker boxes to hold the speakers. I am still working on making a handle. After printing the boxes and brackets I painted them with the "Stone" like spray paint to hide any imperfections. Just add speakers and female USB ports and have at it. Hope this inspires you. If you have any questions give me a shout.

remixed_from.title: Makergear x carriage with LM8UU bearings

description.text:
In a nutshell, this was designed to accommodate an E3D hotend who needs to hang down a little further than most due to the heatsink and fan.  To do this, I slimmed down the platform itself and then moved it downward so it was near flush with the bottom. The revised carriage is the orange part.
This is, as the title suggests, for the Makergear Prusa from yesteryear.  It will not support modern extruders. This seems problematic, but I have been very well served by the original extruder so I don't intend on changing it at the moment.
The LM8UU bearings simply slide in.  I epoxied mine in place and I'd recommend you do something similar. Epoxy is pretty cheap, easy to use, and strong as heck - it just has a bit of a smell for a couple hours ;)

Notes: The settings shown took about 5 hours to print. Ideally, you'd want something like a 0.5mm nozzle, a 0.4mm layer thickness, 230C hotend, and 100C bed. I was going for "pretty" more than speed.

Changes to the wooden insert The lasercut grovemount insert is a tad bit snug. You might want to take a bit of sandpaper or a razor blade to thin it down a tad. As I had to tweak my grovemount holder anyways, I will design a printed part here in a few days that will work better here.
Another 1/87 truck. Printed on Zortrax M200 at 140 micron successfully. Need three 30mm length 1mm brass rods for axles, and 20mm length 1mm brass rod for rear axle pivot.

author: RonPossible

description.text:
Recently on the OpenScad discussion alias, I was trying to explain how I could do my own lighting calculations if given half a chance. Altough it's not really a possibility for the current OpenScad renderer, I got to thinking. Even though I can't print in multiple colors (yet), I can certainly liven up my OpenScad renderings a bit. This thing is a set of imaging routines for OpenScad. The general principle is fairly straight forward. First you need an image to be converted to a format that OpenScad can understand. In the included .zip file, there is such an executable. Just run:
ImageConverter.exe imagename > name.scad This will generate something that looks like:
imagename_triplets_array = [0,0,0, 1,2,3, 255,255,255];
imagename = image(width, height, imagename_triplets_array) There is a new function here: image() which takes parameters necessary to just package up some stuff for later usage in functions. The crux of the routines is actually: image_getpixel(img, x,y) This will return a color value at that point in the image. Nice and handy. But, when you're using images of varying sizes, you don't use pixel coordinates directly, you use normalized values (between 0..1) So, there is another routine: image_gettexel(image, u, v) In this case, the 'u' and 'v' values range from 0..1 That's handy when you're displaying on a bezier surface for example, or a sphere, or anything else that's parametrically defined. You just need to supply the parametric values, and when you go to draw a particular facet, change the color for that facet, and voila!! You've got texture mapping. Just for kicks, there is a luminance() function. What good is that? Well, that allows you to turn an rgb value into a single grayscale value. If you can do that, then you can't be that far away from having a height map generated out of an image. Put it all together and you can take a picture of yourself, convert to OpenScad form, generate a height map, create a mesh that matches the height field (need to do some work for that one), and print out a 3D relief of your face!! Poor man's scan/print if you will. At any rate, it's not complete, and you'll find that you use images of any significant size, your machine will crawl for literally hours. But, if you go back and look at the various font libraries, where you're typically generating 'images' that are 16x12 or something small like that, then suddenly life becomes way easy. If I were into actually contributing to the codebase of OpenScad, rather than just commenting on it, I would suggest that making the array lookups really fast to enable stuff like this without making the machine crawl, would be a very good investment. UPDATE: 21092011
Added blog entry: http://williamaadams.wordpress.com/2011/09/21/openscad-texture-mapping/

1) Download at least the imaging.scad file
2) Download the .zip file to get the ImageConverter.exe (Windows only, sorry)
3) Convert some of your favorite images into .scad format
4) Generate some objects where you can change colors along the way
5) Rejoice! Or just look at the pretty pictures and wonder how they were generated.

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1191246 This is the canopy for the Skywalker 1900. There is one base with a gopro mount (redsalamanders) attached and one regular base plate. I took the files from jointskill, (THANKS!) traced them, and made them simple individual pieces . I have printed one copy out of PLA so far and I am very happy with it. I did file the connecting edges down and they have a nice tight fit. I then welded all the pieces together with Weld-on 4. I also had to cut very small slots in the fuse of the plane where the rear of the canopy fits but that makes a more secure fit. The front end attaches with an M3 screw to the nose of the airplane (if you have the same version I do). I will probably reprint with ABS at some point but for now I am going to work on a pan tilt mechanism. By all means make this better and let me know!! I have the older style SW from hobbyking:
http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__45498__Skywalker_1900_FPV_Glider_EPO_1900mm_Kit_.html

description.text:
This is the newest version of the cooling duct for a FlexMendel printer.  The vents now have a more centralized flow aimed towards the tip of the nozzle.  Both vents have been adjusted so the fit together with 4 M3-8 screws.  This model has a lot more rigidity and allows for better flow.  The secondary vent MUST be printed in ABS to avoid warping.
UPDATE (2/24/2016):  I have adjusted vent 1 so you can take the entire vent off without having to take the fan off.  I HIGHLY recommend printing this part in ABS since it is close to the extruder.

The second vent can be printed without support material. Make sure your printer is first capable of printing this low overhang angle (it's about 25-30 degrees).

title: FoxBlock - High Current - Low Voltage - Electrical Terminal Block

description.text: There is an OpenSCAD file that Foxpup used to create the various part of the "Foxblock", a modular, reconfigurable, high-current, LOW-VOLTAGE, mostly-insulated terminal block made from plastic and very affordable, carefully cut, General Electric Ground Bars. ex: (TGK24CP AND TGK32CP) Why the TGK24CP only has 22 terminals while the TGK32CP has 32 is a matter beyond Foxpup's understanding. (Right up there with why hot dogs come in multiples of 7 while the buns come in multiples of 8 - I guess they want us to by 56 each) // WARNING!!! DANGER!!! Will Robinson!! This device is NOT (i repeat) NOT UL listed and so if someone's house burns down or someone is electrocuted while using this, Foxpup will not accept any guilt or liability. Keep the volage low and Use at your own risk. Like the preparerer of a jumper's parachute, Foxpup has made a best effort to make this product as safe and useable as possible, but if the user does something stupid, the guilt is on their own head. Keep in mind that terminal blocks sometimes get warm, even hot and that PLA plastic gets wibbly-wobbly at ~80 degrees Celsius and liquefies higher up so don't spare the RowCount and/or consider using ABS or nylon if you are really pushing the amps. Foxpup brings this creation as a service to humanity, providing experimenters with inexpensive, mostly-insulated, high current, relatively high quality terminal blocks. Please share and enjoy!! (and PLEASE be careful - we're all trying to be constructive there. :-) If you like this and are feeling generous please consider feeding Foxpup. -> bitcoin:1KTAf3EM1kNWxpKrSSFqbESqYQZf2PAXdm Any amount, large or small, is appreciated, but only give if it brings you joy, not out of a sense of obligation. All the good ideas that Foxpup gets come from the Author of the universe and Foxpup is just passing them on :-) P.S. the 1x16 and 16x1 blocks are meant as more of a joke than anything serious, although a pair of 16x1 parts would fully cover all the terminals of a TGK32CP but would be a challenge not only to print (vertically) but would also be a challenge to get the ground bar into.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.4 mm or better ( I use .2 mm layers )

Notes: This is a rather forgiving design with details that are not that tiny so almost any resolution .5 mm or better should work fine. I did my work at .2 mm because I wasn't in a hurry. The bus bars are best cut with a horizntal band saw. Cutting between the holes is optimal and very doable with a narrow enough blade.
I carefully used a vice to push the "I-Beams" into the 3D printed pieces for a snug fit.

I designed this in openscad and I suppose I could have created a configurator, but I think I have provided enough example stl's to meet most needs.  I appologise thatI live in SAE-land (AKA the US) and was thinking in inches or mounting.  The mounting hole is made to fit a 1/4 inch bolt nicely.  Easy Tweaks to the openscad file would accommodate other sizes. :-)

Notes: The settings to create an assembly versus an individual item has changed with v5. To create the entire assembly, simply enable "createcarraigeassembly", then each individual part of the assembly can be turned on or off. This will generate an assembly that can be exported as a unit. If you disable "createcarraigeassembly" then it will only create the items you specify as enabled, centering them on the build platform.

Measurements and then even more measurements In order to design this, I looked at a series of design drawings and took real world measurements utilizing calipers of the various components. Looking a the manufacturing process of various components allowed me to identify how the wheel carriage assembly would work.

A kinetic sculpture inspired by Arthur Ganson's "Machine with 23 Scraps of Paper". This sculpture consists of 14 "scraps" of PLA, along with associated machination to make it all move. The design is modular in that each individual bird, bird support, and base piece can be clipped together to form chains, or side-by-side configurations. Each row of birds has it's own motor and cams driven by a hex shaft. Remove-able clips connect each modular section, so they can be serviced if needed. For now the birds are glued to the support shaft, a future revision might see these removable as well. See a video here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Twi8_Yn4voE Some assembly required. "combined" parts sets can be used to print all the parts for the gearbox, support, wings, and extras at once. "assembly.skp" can be used as a reference for part assembly.

Assembly Notes "assembly.skp" can be used as a reference for part assembly. Components are designed to be a press fit, and are therefore a tight fit. A small set of files, an x-acto, and a jewelry pin vise are recommended when assembling the components. Be sure to file any bridged portions of the print that come in contact with a bearing, as they tend to droop a little when printing and create friction on the bearing. While the parts fit tightly, the motion should be smooth or the 2-piece hex shaft couplers will pop off. This is by design to relieve stress if there is any binding on the hex shaft. If they do pop off, there is too much friction in the row of cams driven by the hex shafts and the bearing surfaces, vertical shafts, or bird joints need to be cleaned up. A hand crank is provided to turn the hex shaft without the motor to test the smoothness. This can be discarded afterwards. I recommend filing out all of the bearing surfaces, and applying a liberal amount of 3-in-1 oil to moving surfaces to get things moving freely. Also be sure to check for any binding in the metal tube vertical supports as cutting these or having a slight bend can produce quite a bit of resistance. Some parts are glued, mainly the wing support and wing coupler pieces. The metal tubing also may be glued to provide a more solid connection to the wheelcage and riser. Just a dab is all that is required. Be careful not to over do it and get glue on a moving part. Cyanoacrylate and insta-set is recommended. I usually use this stuff: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0000DD1QQ?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s00 http://www.amazon.com/Bob-Smith-151-Insta-Set-Accelerator/dp/B0000DD1QR/ref=pd_bxgy_60_img_3?ie=UTF8&refRID=13TVQ315314VETWBHS24 Components not printed were:
Bird shaft supports: K&S engineering 3/32" aluminum tube (#5101), 1/16" brass tube (#5125), 0.032" music wire (#5501), and 0.020" music wire (#5499) for the wings. Motors are the common 30 RPM 6V variety found here. One motor per row of birds: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B009AQLDSS?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o06_s00 Power supply used was a 5V 1Amp supply. Current draw of the entire sculpture, including LED's and motors, was 200ma. LEDs: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B004UZ3WBU?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o08_s00

title: 1 inch PVC Rocket Fins And Cone

description.text:
A simple Rocket Fins, Cone, And Guide Rails. Steps
1.Cut desired length of 1in PVC pipe. 1 foot works pretty well. 2.Test fit Cone.

  • If the Cone fits good you can use any type of adhesive to stick it on. hot glue, epoxy, super glue, ect.

  • Screw or glue the Fins and Guide rail to the bottom of the PVC pipe.

  • Glue model rocket engine in the bottom of the pipe

  • Light and watch fly. :)

    You can go to my TinkerCAD page to see and edit my other designs At
    https://www.tinkercad.com/users/i9Akvfw1FCy-lower-austin

author: mathew18

title: Hand and Arm for bunraku puppet
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: These are the pieces to create an arm for a BunRaku style puppet. There are additional parts besides the printed pieces necessary.

Print a shoulder piece, and elbow parts 1 and 2. There are two little 'pancakes' at the ends of of Elbow part1, they need to be clipped off. They are there to help those thin ends stay on the platform as it prints. I do not recommend printing the Shoulder and Elbowpt2 vertically. They are stronger when printed horizontally when used in the puppet arm. Print our each hand piece. There are ones for right and left. Glue the 6" long piece of dowel rod into the hole of the shoulder piece.
Glue the other end of the dowel into the Elbow Part #1.
Drill out the hinge holes of both of your elbow parts with a 1/8" drill.
Insert a piece of 3mm plastic filament thru both elbow pieces. THis will act as the hinge pin for the elbow.
Cut the Brass tubing to length.
Insert one end of the Brass tubing into "Arm-Elbow2" opposite of where the hinge is.
Run control rod thru Elbow2 and the brass tubing.
To connect to your hand, you will need to drill a hole the size of your control rod and glue it in place.

comments.text: Thanks for the look at my similar design. Yours looks really good. Your design probably pushes a lot more air than my design, which seems like it could be a good thing except that I find that the extruder heater has a bit of a hard time maintaining the temperature if the fan is going full blast on mine. Your design may block the view of what's going on under the extruder platform more than I'd like, but otherwise looks very practical and functional. Thumbs up! (If anyone else is wondering, my design is http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1012778 )
comments.author: thedayowl

comments.text:
Hey thank for the feedback, it's true that it blocks the view a lot. I've only just started testing it and i guess it would be fine with just one fan in the back, i'm still doing test prints with overhangs and i might try to deactivate one fan to see a real difference.
So far the quality improvements seems notable compared to having no fan.
But regarding the temperature issue i can't confirm that, i have left the nozzle heated up watching the temperature curve and it seem to to be even more stable with the fans on, only dropping maybe 5 degrees but it's stable. so i think i would just up the temperature a bit in the slicer settings next. The air flow gets directed down before it exits the duct.
comments.author: thedayowl

comments.text: I started having clearance issues with my v2 duct design after installing a new heat tube and lower profile extruder nozzle (which I love, by the way - super smooth extrusion), so I spent several hours over the last two days coming up with an entirely new fan duct design. So far I am very happy with how it came out. Check it out at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1242620 and let me know what you think. I still just have my old 40mm fan on it but I have a 50x15 blower like yours on order and I made it modular so I can change out the fan adapter once I get it. I'll be adding the blower adapter the thingiverse post once I get the blower and I get it designed.
comments.author: jandetlefsen

comments.text: Wow, that's good thinking, nice to route it through that gap and free the view of the nozzle. Will give it a try once you got the blower fan version up.
comments.author: thedayowl

comments.text: I received my 50x15 blower today and I have uploaded the adapter design for it.  It does push more air than the 40mm fan does, however I tried connecting the blower directly to 12 volts, and it runs much faster than when connected to the speed-controlled fan circuit on the control board when at 100%.  I'll be investigating the reason the speed controlled output is not ramping up to full power when I get time.  Otherwise, I'm quite pleased with the result.
comments.author: jandetlefsen

comments.text: great, i have simply connected both of my fans to the one that cools down the print head, i noticed that it follows the g-code when i set the first few layer to "not cooling", so i figured that i would apply the same control logic to those fans. it feels like they are not running fast but when i check the air flow it's actually remarkable. tested with bridges and it seem like it's as good as it can get.

description.text: So, you've created a sweet rubber stamp to stamp Mitch Altman's awesome hackerspace passports with. Now what? Are you just going to take that thing and hot-glue it to a block of wood? Well, if you're anything like us, probably. But allow me to suggest an alternative-- print out a custom-sized rubber stamp handle, and issue visas in bureaucratic style!

Edit the stamp_handle.scad file and set the appropriate parameters as described in the file. Run it through openscad, import the STL file and print to taste! You may want to put some fresh blue tape on your platform to help the plate stay extra flat, although it turns out that a little curling is actually OK on a stamp backing. Use some double-sided tape to affix the stamp to the handle, and away you go!

One simple but infuriating problem within making silicone soft robots is making a secure and air-tight connection between the tubing that leads to your air source and the soft robot itself. As a solution to this, I've developed these adapters. Once you cast your soft robot, you can use the Customizer script on this page to make the mold for your adapter. Print it out, cast it, fuse it to your robot, insert the tubing, tighten a zip-tie, and you're done! YouTube video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2bcgIzCQ4Fw

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm - .3mm

Infill:

5%

Notes: Print with 3 shells

Step 1: Customize it to your soft robot First you have to use the Customizer script to generate the mold. Here are the different parameters and what they do: Flange Height: This affects the thickness of the flange (A.K.A. the part that attaches to the soft robot). I recommend any value around 10mm. Flange Radius: This affects the radius of the flange. It should be large enough to fit against the soft robot perfectly. For this value, it is better to be over than under. Sleeve Height: This affects the length of the "sleeve" that the tubing fits into. I recommend any value around 10mm. Tubing Size: For this parameter, put in the outer diameter (OD) of the tubing you are using. For example, if your tubing has an OD of 1/4", convert that to millimeters (6.35mm) and enter that. Once you've entered these parameters, you can download the customized mold and print it using the print settings above. Step 2: Cast it Once you have printed the mold, pour in the same type of silicone you used for the soft robot you are attaching it to. For example, I am using Ecoflex 00-30 for my soft robot, so I'm using Ecoflex 00-30 for my adapter. Let it cure for the required amount of time. Step 3: Attach it to the robot Once the adapter has cured, leave it in the mold and spread some more silicone onto it. Do not use too much. Put the soft robot on top, making sure to align it. Make sure the silicone covers all openings. Let this cure for the required amount of time. Step 4: Secure the connection Once it has cured, pull the now-attached adapter and soft robot out of the mold. Push a screwdriver through the sleeve of the adapter to clear any blockages. Then insert the tubing through the sleeve and into the soft robot. Use a zip-tie and tightly secure it around the sleeve and tube. Step 5: Enjoy Now, you can connect the other end of the tubing to an air source. Happy inflating!

A simple enclosure for a 4g FreedomPop Photon Wifi HotSpot.

I devised a project for myself with the lofty goal of freeing my phone from my cell phone contract. I think it went pretty well! If you pursue a similar option that I did, hopefully the uploaded case helps you out. FreedomPop is a somewhat new service using the Sprint network. For a one-time fee of $40, you can get 500 megabytes of free data every month through a wifi hotspot (called a FreedomPop Photon) that gets mailed to you. When you combine this with the fact that you can make Voice-over-IP calls through Android, you can end up with a service-free phone! The Photon's battery lasts about 6 to 8 hours for me, and I only need to use it when I'm out of Wifi range otherwise. For my project, I have a Samsung Galaxy S3. I found a case on Thingiverse quite easily. However, I wanted to mount my FreedomPop Photon to it. So, I designed the uploaded case. I also designed a Samsung S3 case that has an equally-shaped hole in it, but I don't know that I can upload it since it's a derivative of a work that is now copyrighted some reason. Oh well, it's nothing special. To make use of this case:
  • Get a phone case for your S3. Make sure it's made out of ABS plastic, many cases you can buy are.
  • (optional) Cut a hole in it, which allows you to access the FreedomPop later.
  • Print the FreedomPop Photon case
  • Trim the case so that the FreedomPop Photon within will sit snugly against your phone. (Note that the bottom sheet of the FreedomPop Photon case you printed is quite thin and should be flexible enough to bow to the slightly-bulging shape of the photon.
  • Glue the FreedomPop Photon case to your phone case with acetone.
  • Impress your friends with your ugly case and cancel your phone contract!
    • As you'll see in my photographs, you can save a little additional space so that your resulting case is not so big. It takes a bit more work, though. The idea is to cut down the size of the FreedomPop Photon by eliminating part of its case. Optional steps for the brave:
  • Take off the top cover of the FreedomPop case.
  • Print a replacement cover. (I printed a second FreedomPop Photon case and just stopped it early, then cut it with scissors to size).
  • Replace the original top cover by glueing it on with acetone.
  • When fitting the phone case and FreedomPop Photon case together, align the Photon case so that it will sit with its flat side against the back of the phone.

comments.author: rickyb_667

comments.text: This gets mounted at the bottom of the brackets holding your x axis. I assume this needs to be in the flushest position possible, between your threaded rod and smooth rod, so that when your Z moves and tries to wobble this exerts pressure against your sooth rod. This would make the coupler move (hence the cuts and springlike movement of the coupler) instead of your threaded rod and ultimately your x axis. My question is is this proven? it seems like a lot of pressure to exeert on metal objects. Wouldn't this add friction on y movement? Wouldn't the print leave behing residue and increase the friction even further over time? Wouldn't the print wear down and stop functioning as it was meant to?

Just made it a bit smaller and front faced so I could hold  my wires going to my extruder at the top of my printer.  For some unknown reason it shows the version 1.3 download file as broken up.  It is not.  I posted a pic of it from my printing program to show that it is fine.  (yellow picture)
This was designed for my Prusa i3.
I added my other versions just in case someone can use them instead.
Hope this helps someone.
Thanks to nenadr for the first design that let me remake it into what I needed.

comments.text:
When the carriage goes up during print wires should be able to go through this wire guide. For that reason it should not be tight and its edges must be smooth. I like the minimalistic this one:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2002142
But I will add yours to my collections, too. :-)

Some cycling shoes have soles that are slightly too thick for use with some cleats. This simple thing is a spacer to put under the cleat to make it easier to clip in and out with such shoes.   
I use 0.9mm-thick shims with my Crank Bros. cleats and Keen Commuter sandals, but it may work with other two-bolt walkable cleats.
